Asked about Chris Huhne 's comments, the prime minister's spokesman said today: The position at the present time is that the Crown Prosecution Service are carrying out an assessment of the information that is held by the Metropolitan police. That process is under way and it is up to the CPS to make a decision on their assessment. The prime minister's position is that if there are allegations of illegal behaviour, then those allegations need to be taken very seriously, but in all cases it is a matter for the police and the CPS. The room erupted in applause after one delegate at today's event quizzed Steve Ballmer on the fine print in MS licensing, which could trip up unwary users. Steve Ballmer says he has no plans to simplify licensing. Customers want simplification to reduce costs; our shareholders want simplification without price decreases. Someone may choose a processor based licence for SQL Server, while another may decide on a server-based client access licence. Both offer lower costs depending on how they are deployed.
